2. For 50 years, Christofides' algorithm was the best known algorithm for approximating solutions to TSP (guaranteeing an answer within 3/2 of the optimum) but this year, Anna R. Karlin, Nathan Klein, Shayan Oveis Gharan found and proved that a new algorithm is able to approximate it only off by a factor of 3/2 − ϵ for some ϵ > 10^(−36)!

4. Nim is a game where there are piles of items (usually played with stones) and two players take turns selecting a single pile and removing a non-zero number of stones from that pile. The first player who is unable to make a legal move loses the game.

For a nim game with pile sizes ``x_1, x_2 x_3... x_n``, the game is winning for player 1 iff ``x_1 xor x_2 xor x_3... != 0``
5. My facts from now on will be posted exactly at 12:00 AM PST

6. There is a variant of Nim known as "Staircase Nim". The difference being that in staircase nim, the piles are arranged in a line ``x_1, x_2, x_3...`` and a move takes an arbitrary number of stones from one pile and moves it to the pile directly to it's left. The game ends when all stones are in the left-most pile and the winner is the last person to have made a legal move.

This version of Nim has an equally easy win condition -- a game is won for player 1 iff ``x_2 xor x_4 xor x_6 ... != 0`` (even-indexed piles)
7. Budderball passed away one month ago from congestive heart failure after 13 years of being a good boy

8. There is a HackerRank problem called move the coins, in which you are given a tree with some number of coins in each node. 2 players take turns selecting a node and moving a non-zero number of coins up to its parent. You are asked to determine if player 1 has a winning strategy.

There is an easy solution in O(V+E) if you know fact 6. Just find the distance between every node and the root, then xor all the ones that have odd distance and check if it is 0 or not.

9. Trees always have at least 1 leaf.

Follow any path, by the definition of a tree it cannot end up on itself, so therefore it must end up dangling somewhere else, since this is the end of the path there are no more edges to go through so there must only be one edge which, by definition, makes it a leaf.

20. Some problems are easy. We call all the easy problems P. Specifically, P is the set of problems that have algorithms to solve them that run in polynomial time which means if I multiply the input by some constant, the time it takes to solve increases by some constant. Maybe it's more natural to say that a problem is in P if the solution scales quickly. Very few problems are in P but some examples are:

- Shortest path between two points in a graph -> O(NlogN)
- Finding out if a number if prime. (This was actually a relatively recent result from 2002) -> O((logN)^6) i think
- Greatest Common Factor (This is actually the one of the oldest results ever in algorithm analysis) -> O(logN)

21. Some problems are hard. We call some of the hard problem NP. Specifically, NP is the set of the problems that can be solved in polynomial time if you are mega-lucky. NP stands for "non-deterministic polynomial" which means that it can be solved in polynomial time if you allow for random guessing that also happens to always be the optimal guess. This way of thinking is a bit weird so people usually instead say that NP is the set of problems that, given a solution can be checked in P time. Very few problems are in NP but some examples are:

- Given a set of houses, visit all of them with the shortest possible total distance and end up where you started
- Sudoku
- Chess

Obviously, all P problems are in NP because we can "check" a solution just by solving it and comparing answers.

22. Some problems are impossible. We call these problems undecidable -- they do not get a cool abbreviation because they make us sad. Almost all problems are undecidable, here are some examples:

- Given a some code for a program, determine whether or not it will terminate
- Given a finite set of ``NxN`` matrices, can they be multiplied together in some order (with repetition) to yield the zero matrix?

There is provably no algorithm to solve these problems in finite time.

23. The Halting Problem is undecidable.

The Halting Problem asks: ``Is it possible to create an algorithm that takes in a string P (code for a program) and a string I (an input for that program) and determine whether or not running the program on the input will terminate or not.``

This proof and the paper it's in are probably Alan Turing's most important contribution to computer science.

Proof:

Let's assume there exists an algorithm call it ``halts?``, where ``halts?(p, i)`` returns ``true`` iff P halts on I, otherwise return ``false``
Then consider a second algorithm ``Z`` that does the following: if ``halts? (p,p)`` is ``true`` then loop forever otherwise, halt.

Now, we run ``Z`` on the input Z (the program code for Z)
if ``halts?(Z, Z)`` was ``true``, then we run into an infinite loop because ``Z`` doesn't halt if ``halts? (p,p)`` is ``true``. But that's a contradiction! So therefore, ``halts?(Z, Z)`` must be ``false``. But that means that ``Z`` didn't halt! But it must halt because we halt whenever ``halts?(Z, Z)`` is ``false`` which is another contradiction! So there is no possible consistent output for ``halts?`` and so there is no possible algorithm.

37. Some of the Advent of Code problems are kind of boring and just take a lot of work but day 7 was the first one I felt like took some knowledge

Given lines of input that look like

```
light red bags contain 1 bright white bag, 2 muted yellow bags.
dark orange bags contain 3 bright white bags, 4 muted yellow bags.
bright white bags contain 1 shiny gold bag.
muted yellow bags contain 2 shiny gold bags, 9 faded blue bags.
shiny gold bags contain 1 dark olive bag, 2 vibrant plum bags.
dark olive bags contain 3 faded blue bags, 4 dotted black bags.
vibrant plum bags contain 5 faded blue bags, 6 dotted black bags.
faded blue bags contain no other bags.
dotted black bags contain no other bags.
...
```

Part 1 asks how many bags can contain a ``shiny gold`` bag.

To do this in ``O(n)`` time, construct a directed acyclic graph that connects the "smaller" bags to the "bigger" bags. (There exists an edge from A and B if B contains A)
then, a DFS or BFS sourced from ``shiny gold`` and counting the bags you reach gives the answer.

Part 2 asks how many smaller bags are nested inside a ``shiny gold`` bag.

To do this again in ``O(n)`` time, take the same graph but with the edges reversed! Then the same algorithm (but adding the number of bags instead of just 1) gives the answer

42. I'm behind on the Advent of Code problems but day 11 was somewhat interesting

The input looks like


```
#.##.L#.##
#L###LL.L#
L.#.#..#..
#L##.##.L#
#.##.LL.LL
#.###L#.##
..#.#.....
#L######L#
#.LL###L.L
#.#L###.##
```

Where the ``#`` represents filled chairs, ``L`` represents empty chairs, and ``.`` represents floor (no chair)

We consider the neighbors of a specific chair to be the 8 adjacent chairs (west, northwest, north, northeast...)
We go through rounds where each chair looks at it's neighbors (simultaneously) and if a filled chair has more than 4 filled neighbors it becomes unfilled, and if an unfilled chair has no filled neighbors, then it will become filled.

This problem is probably inspired by John Conway's Game of Life who died this year in Princeton from COVID (RIP)

What is interesting about Conway's Game of Life is that we can prove that it is "Turing-Complete" which means that it can compute anything computable by a computer. In other words, you can take any algorithm that is runnable on a a general computer and run it in Conway's Game of Life (you can find calculators and such built in GOL). Now from this fact, we can prove that it's impossible create an algorithm that takes in a state (an arrangement of chairs) to the GOL, and finds out whether or not it will reach some end state or some set of end states that it cycles between. This follows from the Halting Problem proved in fact 23!!

Assume that you have some algorithm that takes in a GOL state and tells you if it reaches some deadend. Since we can translate any algorithm that can be run on a general computer to a GOL state, if we had such an algorithm we could take some problem, translate it to GOL, and then run our GOL algorithm which would solve the halting problem! But since we know that the halting problem is unsolvable, such an algorithm cannot exist. POG.
43. The Chinese Remainder Theorem is not called just the Remainder Theorem in China. It is still called the Chinese Remainder Theorem.

44. Advent day 13 is so pog it deserves multiple fotds


You're stuck waiting for buses that all have different length routes and as such take different amounts of time to reach the stop you're at.
At the beginning of the day (time 0) all the buses leave to go on their paths and return every ``B_i`` minutes.

The input to the problem looks like this

```
939
7,13,x,x,59,x,31,19
```

Part 1 is kind of boring and just requires some mods. Part 2 is far more difficult and requires maThEMatiCs

It asks, what is the earliest time that we get all the buses arriving in order 1 minute apart. What this means is that we find some time X such that bus 7 arrives at time X, bus 13 arrives at time X+1, bus 59 arrives at time X+4 (4 because in the input, there are two x's which represents buses, while they are not active we still consider them in the time spacing.) and so forth.

```
time     bus 7   bus 13  bus 59  bus 31  bus 19
1068781    D       .       .       .       .
1068782    .       D       .       .       .
1068783    .       .       .       .       .
1068784    .       .       .       .       .
1068785    .       .       D       .       .
1068786    .       .       .       .       .
1068787    .       .       .       D       .
1068788    D       .       .       .       D
```

As shown in the table, 1068781 works because all the buses arrive spaced according to their position in the input list which is what we want. However, in the test input the answer can be massive (> 10^14). We can't try every timebecause that will take too long. So we have to use some maTheMAtiCS!

The first thing to notice is that if we have some time ``X`` that is the solution it means that ``X`` satisfies the congruence ``X = 0 (mod 7)`` and ``X = 12 (mod 13)`` and ``X = 55 (mod 59)`` and so on. If you're a mega-nerd, you know that this is a system of congruences which we can solve using the Chinese Remainder Theorem (see fotd 43)!!!!

How genius is that
